text: (upbeat music)

- Hello, and welcome to
the latest installment
of AWS for Data.
I'm Paddy Fitzpatrick.

I lead the AWS for
Software Companies Business
in the UK and Ireland,
and really pleased to be joined today
by the folks at Tray.io,

a real success story for
the UK software industry.

And I'm joined here today
by Rich, who's the CEO,
and Alin, the Senior Engineering Manager.

Rich, just for those viewer
who are maybe not aware
of what Tray.io does,
could you just tell me
what business problems you look to solve?

- Sure, and thanks for
having us today, Paddy.
The business problem that we solve at Tray
is unlocking all of that trapped data

that lives in the silos
across organizations,
that massively slows down processes,
and ultimately leads to poor performance
within our organizations.

Our customers use the Tray
Universal Automation Cloud
to automate and integrate
all of these different services together.
So that can manifest itself

in things like quote-to-cash
integration for a finance team

or a lead lifecycle process
for a marketing team,
all the way through to data ingestion
or anomaly detection and sharing
from a data team perspective.

So we really work kind
of across an organization
to help unlock all the data
that's trapped within those silos.
- Okay, thank you.

And how would you
summarize Tray.io's journey
with the iPaaS space?

Maybe tell us what iPaaS
is and over the years,
and have you leveraged AWS
to support your strategic growth?

- Yeah, I mean, it's
been a thrilling journey,

and I think as we've seen the
waves of technology evolve
over the last 30 years,

each shift creates a whole
new opportunity for iPaaS.

So customers that are looking
to buy an iPaaS itself,
that's really the place

that you go and do all
of your integration.
That's where you are connecting
to all of the different tools you have,
the databases, the services,
and typically that's done via either code
or a low-code-type interface.
And so the journey that we've been on

is we launched Tray really as
cloud computing was exploding,
and it changed the paradigm
for how people would look to integrate
and connect these services together.

Because suddenly, everything
being hosted in the cloud

created a whole new wave of
challenges for organizations

that were going through
digital transformation.

This last few years has
been really thrilling
because as the sort of evolution of AI
has unfolded in front of us,

that's created a whole new set
of challenges for companies
that not only have to figure out
this automation and integration headache,

but how do we go and infuse
or take advantage of AI
within our automation strategy?

And so for Tray, we've
really put ourselves
at the forefront of that movement.

We are really pushing iPaaS
into a whole new place

by harnessing AI through
the platform itself.
- Excellent. Alin, anything to add?
- The way we leverage AWS in our stack

is by leveraging a lot
of tools across the stack
that complement each other

and help us deliver great
experiences for our customer.

We've invested in building
foundational data systems

that allow us to scale in
line with the business demand
and the customer growth,
and ensuring that we have
the best enterprise tooling available
for our customers' needs.
- Ah, excellent. Thank you.

So let's move on to talk
about data strategy.

So, Rich, how do you align
the company's business goals
in tandem with data strategy and insights?

- Yeah, I think rather
than thinking about them
as an alignment exercise,
really for us,

data strategy is a key
driver in making decisions.
And at every point,
if you think about the breadth of data
that we have available as an organization,
we get a sense of:
What are the latest trends
that our customers are engaging in?
What are some of the problems

that they're trying to solve
within their organizations?
What are some of the titles of the folks
that are starting to tackle automation
and integration for the first time?

And the big change that
Tray brought to the world

was enabling this automation
and integration challenge
to be solved by a much broader audience.

So we now see people
in marketing ops teams,
sales ops teams, finance ops teams

being able to do things that
they previously couldn't.

And so where data kind
of plays a role for us

is we're constantly looking
and trying to refine:

How do we deliver the
right marketing message
to these different audiences?
What's important to them,
as we kind of go through that journey,

a kind of great sort of
near-term example I can give
is we analyzed the usage

across all of our different
customer segments,
and then that helped reshape

how we distributed some
of our marketing spend
into those segments themselves
because we got a better sense of,
"Okay, well, we have a better fit
within this type of organization,
within this type of team,
so let's tighten the message,

let's improve the
enablement for that area."

And then you start to see
really impressive growth

off the back of a much tighter
and much cleaner strategy.
- Yeah, it's interesting you saying
about the new roles evolving,

where we're starting to
see now chief AI officer
as a role coming in.

We wouldn't have seen that
quite a few, quite a while ago,

and we'll come onto AI a
little bit later, but...

So has your journey with
data evolved over the years,
and what were the customer signals

that prompted you to
come up with Merlin AI?

- Yeah, so Merlin, for the
audience that isn't aware,

is the AI that's infused
throughout our entire platform.
And so for us,

that isn't just a natural
language or generative AI approach
that we've taken within the product.
That, obviously, is a component of it,
but it's that we're harnessing AI
through every facet of the platform.
And as Alin will touch on shortly,
one of the key things that we do

is we provide data insights
back to our customers.

So being able to infuse
that with AI itself,

again, is something that is
proven really gainful for us.
How we came up with that sort of idea
or where that signal came from
actually goes back to the genesis

of building the company
in the first place.
When we started building the platform,

it was because we wanted
to harness the power
of APIs and computing
in a way that didn't require somebody

to write a full application,
deploy it, load balance it,

test it, and manage it
on an ongoing basis.
We abstract that away from the customer.
So we provide this low-code method
that allows you to go and do that.
So if you think from day one,
what we've really been trying to do
is democratize programming.

We've been trying to
make it easier for people
to create really robust solutions

and take the sort of the
components that you need
to build a powerful application

and break it down into something
that's easy to maintain,
easy to manage, easy to govern,
but most importantly is secure.
And so really for us,

it's such a natural fit
starting to drive Merlin

because it continues to
lower that barrier of entry.

It continues to make it
easier for people to do things
that they previously couldn't.
And so the signals that drove us to that

really sort of aligned
to what I was just saying
in terms of looking at how customers
engage with the platform.

Where do we see opportunities
for a better experience?
Or where is there maybe a roughness
in how somebody's trying to complete

maybe a data manipulation
within a workflow itself?
As we then played around
with the concepts that Gen AI bought,
it opened up a whole new way
for us to be able to serve the customer.

And so those signals are
not just data-driven,

but they're also really the
sort of driving instinct

of why we bought Tray to the
world in the first place.
- And I know that you've had
some recognition of this recently.
- We have, yeah.
We are delighted to announce this week

that we've been recognized
in the Vision Week Quadrant

in Gartner's MQ that
was launched yesterday.

And for us, that is
not only a proud moment

for our company and on
behalf of our customers,
but really an indication
that we are really looking down the road
for where iPaaS goes.
And I think that that, to me,
is the most critical part of this.

iPaaS evolves through
every single generation
and through every software shift,

and it's clear that
we're right in the midst
of a major change for everybody.
- Yeah,

and for us that have been
working with you for years,

it's nice to see that
that broader recognition
of the visionary nature

of the organization and
technology that you have.

- Thank you.
- Okay.
So let me move on to...
Alin, I've got a question for you.

So, yeah, as a universal
automation platform,
Tray has unique data insights

that can benefit your
customer's performance.

So how do you think about
using this as a differentiator,
especially on the gen AI side of things?
- Sure, so as Rich was mentioning,
customers use Tray to power a lot

of their business-critical
processes internally

by building integrations and
automation on our platform.
A lot of the times,

they build these
integrations and automations
on behalf of their own customers

to provide them as a solution
to them as the end user.

And we use our data systems
and our data platform
to inform all of those business processes,
provide insights at every level,
be it in real time or aggregations,
and things that require further enrichment
with various data points

that are generated
throughout the platform.

On top of this, gen AI can
help analyze workflow data.
It can dynamically adapt workflows
based on AI recommendations,
as well as create...

Ultimately helping them create
customized automation paths
in their organization.

Tray platform can also
automate routine decision.
This can assist in decision making,

real-time insights can
enable faster response
and better customer experiences.

It can predict potential
bottlenecks in your organization
or in your business processes

and highlight failures
and resource shortages.
So overall, we believe that insight

is gonna provide a holistic
improvement of the experience

and help make the automations
more performant and efficient.
- Wow, that's a lot to back in there.
And if I...

You've obviously had to make
a lot of technology decisions
over the years,
so just tell me a little bit more
about your technology landscape

and the sort of decisions
you've made on technology.
- Sure.

We've built a comprehensive
data platform on AWS.
To give you some example, we use Kafka MSK
for stream processing.
We use Redshift for our data warehousing.
We use Spark and EMR for batch processing,
as well as Airflow for data orchestration.
And we're experimenting with Flink
for real-time stream processing
to get that extra bit of insights.
We are addressing distinct needs
with these technologies.

We're looking at
purpose-driven functionality.
These are powerful systems.
They're versatile, managed,
highly available, fault-tolerant.
Scalability is obviously very important.
So we want system that scale horizontally
in line with the business demand
and with the growth of our company,

but also our customers'
implementations and applications.

We are looking to handle a
large amount of data volumes

and try to maintain
performance while doing that.

Security is obviously a very
important consideration.
We're looking at encryption,
we're looking at proper IAM roles
and security asset controls.
- Thanks, Alin, that's really insightful.

I know, I think you use over
30 AWS services in your stack,

so it's great to see
such an a advanced use
of the stack that we have.
So, Rich, if I'll come to you,
we talked about data insights

and the data insights you
provide to your customers.

I think, ultimately, that
they can provide to theirs.
So how do you make sure in development,

enhancement of products, that
data insights are built in?

- Yeah, I mean, it's a
critical part of the process.
And for me and for us as a company,
data is a really important guide.

It shouldn't be the
complete decision-maker.
It doesn't give you the full picture,
but it does give you the direction
and it does help you find the path

to ultimately build a better
solution for your customer.
So for our product team,
part of their process is looking at:

How is that functionality
currently being consumed?
What is the usage look like?
Are there obvious blockers
in the way that the product itself

is actually being utilized
by the end customer?
And so a kind of a good example of that,
the way that our workflows are structured.
Historically, that would be kind of...
They'd be split up and run individually.
We switched over to a project-based model

that would allow you to keep
all of the assets in one place.

And we instantly saw more
deployment, faster deployment,

and quicker time to promotion
for our organizations
because of that subtle product shift.
- Excellent, and what sort of feedback

have you had from your
customers about that?

- I mean, the feedback
on that was fantastic,

and nonetheless, because
it also allowed us
to pass on a saving back to the customer.

And that's a little trick that
we actually learned from AWS,

which is by being able
to go out to a customer
and have like a consumptive model

and then show best practice
for how you actually go

and deploy this stuff
effectively and efficiently.
Yes, you save your customer money

and you demonstrate a way
that they can get more value,
but it also increases the footprint
of other services that they use with you.

And so we've taken a little
leaf out of your book there.
- Yeah, excellent.
So when we think about product management
and the world of software today,
we hear a lot of feedback from customers
who want to buy SaaS,

and a lot of my software
companies that we work with
actually are trying to develop SaaS.
So for a business that's maybe starting

on the journey towards
software as a service,
what advice would you give them?
- I think the world has changed so much
in this past couple of years,
and you've gotta think about:
What is the buying process gonna look like
for that end customer?

What is the demand that
you are solving for?

Where does this fit in
the portfolio of services
that they already have?
And I think for a long time,
SaaS played a role

of being a number of
kind of wedge products
that existed between major systems

that would hold, say, sales
data or customer data,
or on the personnel side, HR data.

And you'd find there'd be
lots of little opportunities

to create applications
that would sit in between.

I think as we're starting
to see that world shift
and as we're starting to see

a more natural integration of
data between these services,

that's kind of limited what
that footprint looks like.

And so as organizations are
looking to make that shift
and they're looking to change the way
that they enable their customers to buy,
they've really gotta think about:
What is this deployment gonna look like?

How does it fit into the
ecosystem that I'm already in?

And ultimately, who are
the key decision makers
that are gonna be making this purchase?
Because that's actually as important
as the deployment model itself.
- Yeah, definitely.

So we have, yeah, a lot of
conversations with our customers

around the business aspects
of software as a service,
and pricing, and training Salesforce,

paying Salesforce or
all different elements,
as well as the technical ones.
So, as we wrap up this,
I'd just like to get your views

on what next for Tray.io in
terms of your data strategy

and where you see the company
going over the next few years.
- Yeah, I alluded to it a little bit
at the start of our conversation,

which is, for us,
traditional iPaaS is dying,
and the iPaaS has gotta change, right?
We can't go and look to buy something
that was built 20, 30 years ago

that was deploying in
a fragmented code base
with an inelastic architecture.
One of the benefits that we've had
from working with AWS for so long
is our software is lightning quick.

And in a world that is moving
as fast as it is today,

the speed at which your
automations can be deployed,
the speed at which you want to get
that real-time information back

is absolutely critical
in making these changes.
And as we look ahead,
it's very clear that the world is shifting
toward this AI-enabled enterprise.

We're actually coining it
the autonomous enterprise,
which is a world where AI agents
play a much more important role
in proactively and reactively
supporting you and your organization

as you improve your
go-to-market operation.

And so all of our efforts,
and our investments,

and our focus, and our data
strategy is aligned around:

How can we harness this amazing
technology to our customers?
Because it's evident to us

that this is the path
the world's going in,

and we can be right at
the forefront of that.
- Excellent, very exciting future.
So, well, I want to thank you, Rich,

and thank you, Alin, for
taking the time today.

Also, thank you for your
years of building on AWS

and to help us both serve
our joint customers.
And yeah, really exciting future ahead,
especially with gen AI

and the AI-enabled
features that you'll have.

So thank you all for coming
and watching our session today.
And for any information,

more information on Tray.io
and to follow your journey,

how do they get in touch?
- Yep. Please look us up.

Tray.io, we're on all the
socials, as you can imagine.
So, I look forward to seeing you there.
- Excellent. Thank you.
